symptom: Overall network speed is significantly slow during peak hours
conditions: `iperf` tests show bandwidth significantly below expected levels
Router/switch CPU utilization is consistently high (e.g., > 80%)
Interface statistics (`show interface` on Cisco, `ip -s link show` on Linux) show high utilization or output drops
diagnosis: Network congestion, insufficient bandwidth, or overburdened network devices
solution: Identify bandwidth-intensive applications or users using NetFlow/sFlow or `iftop`/`nethogs`
Upgrade core network devices (router, switches) to higher capacity models if CPU/memory is the bottleneck
Implement QoS (Quality of Service) policies to prioritize critical traffic and de-prioritize less important traffic
Consider increasing the internet uplink bandwidth from the ISP
Segment the network into smaller broadcast domains or introduce faster backbone links
Review network topology for any bottlenecks or single points of failure

symptom: High latency and packet loss observed during ping tests to internal servers
conditions: Continuous ping tests show inconsistent RTT (Round Trip Time) and frequent timeouts
`traceroute` to affected servers shows increased latency at a specific hop or multiple hops
Error counters on switch interfaces (e.g., FCS errors, collisions, discards) are incrementing rapidly
diagnosis: Faulty cable, duplex mismatch, congested switch port, or faulty network adapter
solution: Inspect and replace suspicious Ethernet cables or patch panel connections
Verify duplex settings on both ends of the link (workstation NIC and switch port) are set to 'auto' or 'full-duplex'
Move the connection to a different port on the network switch to rule out a faulty port
Update or reinstall network adapter drivers on the server or workstation
Check for excessive broadcast storms or network loops (use `spanning-tree show` on switches)
Analyze switch logs for port error messages or unusual activity

symptom: Specific application performs poorly over the network, while others are fine
conditions: Network monitor tools show the application's traffic experiencing retransmissions or dropped packets
Application logs report network-related errors or timeouts
Server hosting the application shows high I/O wait or CPU utilization during application usage
diagnosis: Application-specific network tuning issues, server-side bottleneck, or misconfigured QoS
solution: Review the application's network requirements and recommended configurations (e.g., TCP window size, MTU)
Optimize the application server's resources (CPU, RAM, disk I/O) if it's the bottleneck
Ensure QoS policies are not inadvertently de-prioritizing the application's traffic
Perform `netstat -s` on the server to check for TCP segment retransmissions or errors
Consult the application vendor's documentation for network performance best practices
Isolate the issue using `iperf` or `nuttcp` to measure raw TCP/UDP throughput to the application server

symptom: Wireless clients experience very slow speeds despite good signal strength
conditions: Speed tests on wireless clients show low throughput (e.g., using Fast.com or Ookla Speedtest)
Wireless network reports high channel utilization or many co-channel/adjacent-channel interference
Many older wireless devices (802.11b/g) are connected to the same access point as newer ones
diagnosis: Wireless interference, outdated Wi-Fi standards, or overloaded access point
solution: Use a Wi-Fi analyzer tool to identify channel interference and select a less congested channel for the access point
Separate 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz networks and encourage clients to use 5 GHz where possible
Disable legacy 802.11b/g rates on the access point if not needed, as they slow down the entire network
Consider adding more access points to distribute client load and improve coverage
Update access point firmware to the latest version for performance improvements
Ensure that the access point is configured for the highest possible 802.11 standard it supports (e.g., 802.11ac/ax)

symptom: Upload speeds are significantly slower than download speeds (asymmetrical performance)
conditions: Speed tests consistently show a large disparity between upload and download rates
ISP modem diagnostics show high noise levels or errors on the upstream channel
QoS policies on the router are configured to prioritize downloads over uploads excessively
diagnosis: ISP's asymmetrical service, upstream noise, or QoS misconfiguration
solution: Verify the ISP's contracted upload and download speeds to ensure the observed speeds match expectations
Check ISP modem diagnostics for upstream signal strength, SNR (Signal-to-Noise Ratio), and corrected/uncorrected errors
Review and adjust QoS configurations on the router to ensure fair bandwidth allocation for uploads
Ensure no applications or services on the network are saturating the upload bandwidth (e.g., cloud backups, file sharing)
Bypass the router and test directly with the ISP modem to rule out the router as the bottleneck
Contact the ISP to report potential line quality issues affecting upload performance

symptom: Video conferencing quality is poor (pixelation, audio drops)
conditions: Video conferencing application reports high jitter, packet loss, or network latency
During calls, `ping` tests to the video conference server show high latency spikes
Firewall or router logs show dropped packets related to UDP ports used by video conferencing
diagnosis: Insufficient bandwidth, lack of QoS, or firewall blocking/inspecting UDP traffic
solution: Ensure sufficient bandwidth is available for video conferencing calls (check application requirements)
Implement QoS policies on the network to prioritize voice and video traffic (DSCP markings, bandwidth reservation)
Verify that firewalls are not inspecting or blocking UDP traffic for common video conferencing ports
Check for network congestion on critical links during video calls using network monitoring tools
Reduce the number of concurrent bandwidth-heavy activities during calls if bandwidth is limited
Use a wired connection instead of wireless if possible, as wireless can introduce more jitter and packet loss

symptom: Backup operations to a network-attached storage (NAS) are extremely slow
conditions: File transfer speeds to the NAS are much lower than expected (e.g., using `scp` or file explorer)
NAS resource utilization (CPU, disk I/O, network interface) is high during backups
Network interface statistics on the NAS or switch show excessive retransmissions or errors
diagnosis: NAS performance bottleneck, network congestion to NAS, or faulty cabling/NIC
solution: Check the NAS's hardware resources (CPU, RAM, disk health) for bottlenecks or issues
Ensure the NAS network interface is operating at its maximum supported speed and duplex (e.g., Gigabit Full Duplex)
Verify the cable connecting the NAS to the switch is adequate (e.g., Cat5e/Cat6 for Gigabit)
Check the switch port connected to the NAS for errors, discards, or excessive utilization
Consider bonding multiple NICs on the NAS for increased throughput (Link Aggregation)
Review backup software configuration for optimization settings (e.g., block size, compression)

symptom: Remote office users complain about slow access to central servers
conditions: Ping and `traceroute` tests from the remote office to central servers show high latency and sometimes packet loss
WAN link utilization at the remote office or central site router is consistently high (e.g., > 90%)
Firewall throughput logs show high CPU utilization or packet inspection delays
diagnosis: WAN link saturation, router/firewall bottleneck, or routing inefficiencies
solution: Monitor WAN link utilization on both ends to confirm bandwidth saturation is the cause
Upgrade the WAN link bandwidth if consistently saturated during business hours
Ensure WAN optimization or SD-WAN solutions are correctly configured and performing as expected
Check router/firewall CPU and memory utilization at peak times; upgrade hardware if needed
Review routing configurations to ensure optimal paths are being used for remote office traffic
Implement QoS on the WAN links to prioritize critical business applications over less critical traffic

symptom: Web Browse is intermittently slow on multiple workstations
conditions: Browser response times are inconsistent, with pages sometimes loading quickly and sometimes very slowly
DNS resolution appears to be fast, but subsequent page loading is slow
Network monitoring tools show high TCP retransmission rates on client connections to external websites
diagnosis: Internet uplink congestion, transparent proxy/firewall inspection, or ISP peering issues
solution: Run speed tests (e.g., Speedtest.net) to verify current internet bandwidth
Check the internet router's CPU and memory utilization, especially during periods of slow Browse
If a transparent proxy or content filter is in place, check its resource utilization and logs for bottlenecks
Bypass the router and connect a workstation directly to the ISP modem to rule out internal network issues
Contact your ISP to inquire about any network congestion or peering issues on their side
Consider implementing web caching or local DNS caching to improve Browse experience

symptom: Database queries from client machines are very slow
conditions: Database server logs indicate slow query execution times from the network perspective
Network latency from clients to the database server is consistently high (e.g., > 10ms)
Database server shows high disk I/O or CPU usage during query execution
diagnosis: Database performance issues, network latency, or inefficient database queries
solution: Optimize database queries by adding indexes, rewriting inefficient queries, or denormalizing data
Ensure the database server has sufficient resources (CPU, RAM, fast storage like SSDs)
Minimize network latency between the database clients and server (e.g., co-locate them in the same data center)
Check for network congestion or errors on the path to the database server
Implement connection pooling on the client side to reduce connection setup overhead
Review database server network configuration (e.g., TCP buffer sizes)

symptom: Intermittent throughput issues for specific file transfers over SMB/NFS
conditions: File copy operations pause or resume unexpectedly, with fluctuating transfer rates
Network interface statistics show bursts of activity followed by periods of inactivity
Server or client logs show I/O errors or network disconnect messages during transfers
diagnosis: Faulty network cable/NIC, driver issues, or server-side storage performance bottlenecks
solution: Replace the Ethernet cable connecting the affected client/server to the switch
Update or reinstall network adapter drivers on both the client and the file server
Check the health and performance of the storage array on the file server (RAID status, disk I/O latency)
Ensure the network interface on the file server is operating at its full capacity and duplex
Temporarily disable antivirus or security software on client/server to rule out interference
Verify sufficient RAM on the file server for caching and buffering large file transfers

symptom: Packet loss observed on a specific WAN link during high traffic
conditions: Ping tests across the WAN link show consistently high packet loss (> 5%) during certain periods
Router interface statistics for the WAN link show input/output drops or errors
Bandwidth utilization on the WAN link approaches its maximum capacity
diagnosis: WAN link congestion, faulty router interface, or incorrect QoS settings causing drops
solution: Monitor the WAN link utilization using SNMP or NetFlow to confirm congestion
Implement or adjust QoS policies to prioritize critical traffic and manage congestion effectively
Check for any duplex mismatches on the WAN interface or connected equipment (e.g., ISP CPE)
Review router CPU and memory utilization; high usage can lead to packet drops
If persistent, contact the ISP to report potential link quality issues or consider upgrading bandwidth
Perform an extended ping test with larger packet sizes to stress the link and observe patterns

symptom: Virtual machine network performance is poor on a hypervisor host
conditions: VMs on a specific host show slower network throughput compared to VMs on other hosts
Hypervisor host's network adapter utilization is high or reports errors
Guests' CPU or memory utilization is low, indicating network is the bottleneck
diagnosis: Hypervisor network configuration, physical NIC bottleneck, or driver issues on host
solution: Verify the hypervisor's virtual switch configuration (e.g., VMWare vSwitch, Hyper-V Virtual Switch) for correct settings
Ensure the physical NICs on the hypervisor host are adequate (e.g., 10GbE) and properly configured (e.g., Jumbo Frames if used)
Update hypervisor network adapter drivers and firmware to the latest versions
Check for resource contention on the hypervisor host (e.g., CPU, RAM for network processing)
Consider using dedicated physical NICs for different types of VM traffic (e.g., vMotion, iSCSI, VM Network)
Verify VM network adapter types (e.g., VMXNET3 for VMWare, Synthetic for Hyper-V) for optimal performance

symptom: IP Camera streams are laggy and frequently disconnect
conditions: Video surveillance software shows dropped frames or 'connection lost' messages for specific cameras
Ping to the camera IP addresses shows high latency or timeouts
Network switches connected to the cameras show high utilization or errors on those specific ports
diagnosis: Network congestion, insufficient bandwidth for streaming, or faulty camera/cabling
solution: Verify that sufficient network bandwidth is available from the camera to the NVR/monitoring station
Check for network congestion on switches or routers in the camera's path (e.g., broadcast storms)
Ensure Power over Ethernet (PoE) switch ports are providing adequate power for the cameras
Inspect the network cable connecting the camera for damage or loose connections
Reduce the resolution, frame rate, or bitrate of the camera streams if bandwidth is limited
Consider using dedicated VLANs for IP camera traffic to isolate it from other network traffic

symptom: Slow performance of external cloud services or SaaS applications
conditions: Internal applications perform well, but access to cloud services is consistently slow
`traceroute` to the cloud service endpoint shows high latency at hops outside your internal network (e.g., ISP or peering points)
Internet router CPU/memory is low, indicating the bottleneck is not internal
diagnosis: ISP congestion, peering issues, or cloud provider regional issues
solution: Contact your ISP to report observations of slow connectivity to specific external endpoints
Check cloud provider status pages or forums for reported regional issues or outages
Consider using a different DNS resolver (e.g., 8.8.8.8, 1.1.1.1) to ensure optimal routing to cloud services
If using direct cloud connect (e.g., AWS Direct Connect, Azure ExpressRoute), verify its status and utilization
Implement SD-WAN solutions to intelligently route cloud traffic over optimal paths
Perform `mtr` (My Traceroute) to the cloud service IP to get continuous latency and packet loss data

symptom: Network-attached scanner takes a long time to transfer scanned documents
conditions: Scanning process completes slowly, especially for large documents or multiple pages
Network monitor shows low throughput during the transfer from the scanner to the destination
Destination storage (e.g., network share) shows high disk I/O when documents arrive
diagnosis: Scanner network interface limitation, network congestion, or destination storage bottleneck
solution: Verify the scanner's network interface speed (e.g., 100Mbps vs. Gigabit) and ensure it's operating at its maximum
Check the network cable connecting the scanner to the switch
Ensure the destination server/NAS has sufficient disk I/O performance to handle incoming scans
Reduce the resolution or file size of scanned documents if possible to decrease network load
Check for network congestion between the scanner and its destination
Update scanner firmware or network drivers for potential performance improvements

symptom: Remote access gateway (e.g., Citrix, Terminal Services) experiences slow logon times
conditions: Users report significant delays during the logon process to published applications or desktops
Network latency from clients to the gateway is acceptable, but latency from gateway to backend servers is high
Gateway server's CPU or memory utilization is high during logon storms
diagnosis: Backend server performance, network congestion to backend, or gateway resource exhaustion
solution: Monitor backend servers (domain controllers, database servers, application servers) for performance bottlenecks (CPU, RAM, disk I/O)
Check network latency and throughput between the gateway and backend servers
Ensure the gateway server has sufficient CPU, RAM, and fast storage for its role
Review gateway logs for errors related to authentication, profile loading, or session establishment
Optimize logon scripts or Group Policy Objects (GPOs) that might be delaying the process
Implement network QoS to prioritize authentication and application traffic to/from the gateway

symptom: Network monitoring system (NMS) shows frequent device unreachable alerts
conditions: NMS sends alerts for devices that are confirmed to be online and operational
Ping tests to the 'unreachable' devices from the NMS server show intermittent timeouts or packet loss
NMS server itself is not overloaded (CPU/memory utilization is low)
diagnosis: Network congestion impacting NMS polling, SNMP agent issues, or NMS misconfiguration
solution: Increase the polling interval for devices in the NMS to reduce network load and false positives
Verify SNMP community strings or credentials are correct on the devices and NMS
Check for network congestion between the NMS server and the monitored devices (e.g., WAN links)
Ensure the NMS server's network interface and connectivity to the network are stable
Review device syslog or SNMP trap logs for any messages related to network interface flapping or errors
Consider distributing NMS polling agents closer to remote network segments

symptom: Large file transfers over SFTP/FTP are slower than expected
conditions: Observed transfer rates are consistently below the rated network link speed (e.g., 100Mbps on a Gigabit link)
Server or client CPU utilization is low, indicating not a processing bottleneck
SFTP/FTP logs show retransmissions or delayed acknowledgements
diagnosis: TCP window size issues, firewall/NAT traversal problems, or disk I/O bottleneck on server/client
solution: Ensure TCP window scaling is enabled on both the SFTP/FTP client and server operating systems
Check the MTU settings along the network path to prevent fragmentation and reassembly overhead
Verify the performance of the disk subsystem on both the source and destination for I/O bottlenecks
Review firewall configurations for any deep packet inspection or NAT traversal issues affecting large transfers
Try different SFTP/FTP client software or server implementations to rule out software-specific issues
Use tools like `iperf` or `nuttcp` to test raw TCP throughput between the endpoints to isolate network vs. application performance

symptom: Virtualized desktop infrastructure (VDI) sessions are laggy and unresponsive
conditions: Users report slow mouse movements, delayed keyboard input, and pixelation within VDI sessions
Network latency from thin clients/workstations to VDI brokers/hosts is consistently high
VDI host CPU/memory/disk I/O utilization is within acceptable limits
diagnosis: Network latency/jitter to VDI infrastructure, insufficient bandwidth, or display protocol issues
solution: Minimize network latency and jitter between VDI clients and the VDI infrastructure (brokers, session hosts)
Ensure sufficient network bandwidth for VDI sessions, especially for rich media or graphics-intensive workloads
Optimize the VDI display protocol settings (e.g., compression, image quality) to match available bandwidth
Check for network congestion on switches and routers in the VDI traffic path
Consider using a dedicated network segment for VDI traffic to isolate it from other network contention
Upgrade network infrastructure to 10GbE or higher where VDI hosts and storage are connected
